FAMILY~
U.S. schools soft on exercise, health
By PATRICIA McCORMACK
Some Johnnies and Janies in U.S.
schools munch junk food, drive too fast,
habits
drink too much alcohol, test narcotics, be-
come mothers and fathers before gradua-
tion or marriage, get venereal disease -
and even kill themselves.
Many also sit too much, eat too much, grow fat
and predispose themselves to heart ailments and
strokes in adulthood.
In public health circles, all events. like those
listed above are called "self-destructive habits."
Which gives rise to the question:
"Why aren't schools warning kids that the
payoff for self-destructive behavior is a shorter,
disease-riddled life?"
Well, some schools are trying - within limits.
But a lot of school bosses are saying they don't
ave money for health promotion on the scale really
necessary to make an impact.
Ohters say no one really asked them to get into
his partof health in a big way.
Now Dr. Julius B. Richmond, Assistant Secre-
ary for Health, U.S. Department of Health, Educa-
ion and Welfare (HEW), wants the nation's schools
do more to help students control destructive
abits.
Say health promoters: give kids the facts about
lcohol, smoking, etc.. and let them make the deci-
ion to stay on or get off a self-destructive path.
Pleads for health promotion
In a new report, "Healthy People," U.S. Surgeon
eneral Richmond pleads for, among other pro-

rams, hyped-up health promotion and disease
tion curricula should help a child make intelligent
revention in the academic setting.
decisions about smoking, as well as about other be-
Health education and disease prevention is the
havior that affects health. :
ation's second health revolution, then HEW. Secre-.

ary Joseph Califano Jr. said when releasing the
part of the school curriculum.

—Physical fitness: For children and adoles-;
nd of July.
cents, exercise too often involves an emphasis on

ectious diseases.

Young, middle-aged and old can get with this
ducted physical education programs that could help

promote lifetime habits of physical exercise as well
ng more responsibility on themselves for what hap-
as contribute to child growth and development.
ens to their health. They must recognize, ·in old-

ashioned terms, that if they burn the candle at both
school physical education programs have had to cut
ends, the wick won't last as long.
back for lack of adequate state and local funding.
